Expectation1: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation1: The acquaintance is in a group where people are talking about the recent decisions of a mutual colleague.
Situation2: They review a construction project where certain elements could pose safety risks if not corrected before work continues.
Story: I stood at the edge of the break room, coffee in hand, as the conversation swirled around me. My colleagues were dissecting the latest project decisions made by Mark, a mutual acquaintance. I felt the familiar pressure to join in, to nod along or add my own opinion, but I remembered my promise to myself: never gossip, never speak ill of others behind their backs. Yet, as an architect, I had just reviewed Mark’s latest plans and noticed a few elements that, if left unaddressed, could compromise the building’s safety. My professional duty demanded I speak up, to ensure compliance and protect everyone involved. But here, in this group, any comment could easily slip into criticism, feeding the gossip I wanted to avoid. My mind raced, torn between the urge to protect my colleague’s reputation and the responsibility to uphold safety standards. The weight of both roles pressed on me, and I hesitated, unsure which expectation I could afford to betray.
